@timtay-microsoft  , you rightfully mentioned that we shouldn't be using this implementation and there is an out of the box Pair class in java.
I found javafx.util.Pair implementation ... is that the one you had in mind?
My mistake on this one. I thought there was a pair class within Java's collection namespace, but apparently there isn't. This one should be fine, though, sure.

For reference, there is an interface defined for a class like Pair in Map: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Map.Entry.html
But the implementation is private, so we have no access to it
Don't hardcode "10" into this message. Use the value from the variable below, in case we ever change its value
Since we are using log.debug everywhere else, can you switch these from System.out to log.info or log.debug?
Add a header here if only to clarify that the multiplexClientId is user-defined, and isn't some Id like deviceId where they get it from the portal.
I'd suggest swapping this condition to handle the positive case first
space after if

Is openClient() synchronous, such that after it completes we can be sure we're connected?
Shouldn't we wait for a callback that says we're connected to change this internally tracked state to connected?
Yes, it is synchronous.
What do you think about using the callback confirmation to change the cached state vs. setting it here?

You mean in the execute method instead of doConnect ? sure, we can certainly do that, I am curious to know why you think that's a better approach?
as I mentioned, if openClient doesn't throw, it means it successfully established the connection. also, the "connection status change callback" is basically invoked every time there is a change, and that doesn't exactly (or "accurately") maps to the states we are maintaining in this class.
Because getting confirmation from the SDK client that we've connected is more affirmative than asserting it should be connected.
Suggest changing this to != connecting, and return, so the remaining code doesn't have to be tabbed in 1 more
Why is locking not necessary here when changing this state but is elsewhere?
The finally statement is also in the synchronized block. Am I missing something?

I wasn't looking broadly enough to see it is in a larger lock. Do we want this entire operation locked?
I thought the lock was just for conditionally acting on and changing the state of the cached last known connection status

This block is updating the connectionStatus and opening the client (in which if there is no exceptions, means it's successful) ... so I think having it in the synchronized block is justified .
Did I understand your comment correctly?
very inconsistent brace usage in this file
fixing.
lastKnownConnectionStatus?
I like that
It doesn't handle that state. It detects that state, right?

Given this is a sample and that the task is complex, it is going to need way more code comments.
I'd like to see high level approach, and then for each method how it fits into the larger picture.

nodes.bodyText: Does Java share this antipattern with C#? That is, throw ex; vs throw;?
no, you always have to throw an exception in the throw statement.
callback is 1 word
Perhaps this belongs on the client wrapper classes we have?
I think that would complicate the logic in client managers unnecessarily. Let's discuss this further if you feel really strongly about this.
Where is this used?
Just for logging, I guess?
correct.

Perhaps that makes me wonder why the multiplexing client doesn't have a way to uniquely identify it.
Anytime we have to write code in our samples (especially each time), I think that is a sign we are missing something in our client library. Do you agree?

well, the question is how would you actually uniquely identify the multiplexing client? we either have to assign a random identifier to it as a metadata upon initialization, or take it as an input form the user. I don't know how much value there is in providing extra metadata to identify the multiplexing client ...

The multiplexing client doesn't need to be identified to the service, but it would be for local use, as you've done with logging. I'd make it an optional, read-only property on the multiplexing client. If not provided, we could initialize it with a GUID - maybe not.

I think at this stage since this is a sample code and it's only used for logging purposes taking it as a parameter in the constructor is reasonable. but I do agree that if at some point users start managing multiple multiplexingClients in their code, there might be a good argument that these clients should be easily identifiable which requires the core SDK logic to change (which is an addition and should be fine)
Why wouldn't this be set to DISCONNECTED?
The DISCONNECTED status represents a final disconnected (and not going to retry) status. Connecting is basically saying, we are trying to open this connection and it's not yet connected.
That might be evident to a sample reader, such as myself, if the enum values had comments describing what they are and when they are used
Comments added
Any reason not to use the same exception variable name throughout? We have ex and e in some places.
The class comment says this is the base class for device and multiplexing manager clients, but this comment mentions the device client.
my bad, fixing.

How might/should the multiplexing connection status callback calls (where the status is disconnected_retrying) affect the device client manager statuses? They may still think they are connected, but they aren't. Or are they getting the callback too, and if so, what action are they taking?
let's chat about this in the live review together.
What's the difference between getClientId() and suppliedCallbackPair.getValue()? Are they both the device Id?
in this case, yes, they are both deviceId/multiplexing client Id
Seems could be a source of confusion for a sample reader when we use both in the same function.
The suppliedCallbackPair is removed. We no longer have this issue.
2 spaces after return => 1
space before brace
In .NET we'd make this abstract to ensure the inheriting class implemented it. Does Java have an analog?

There is the same concept in java, I didn't make it abstract because there is nothing to override, we don't want the subclasses to do anything with this, we just want to make sure the call is delegated to the ClientManager and it doesn't do anything. we can discuss it in more depth if you like.
Why closeNow() instead of just close()?

That is an excellent question.
DeviceClient has two different method signatures, close() and closeNow(). close() has been deprecated
client managers for both DeviceClient and MultiplexingClient are setup such that any call that you make to them they will delegate to the inner client except for open, close and registerConnectionStatusCallback
Now there are 2 different method signatures on the DeviceClient for closing the connection, and we want to make sure we delegate those calls to the client manager and it knows how to override both of those methods.
As previous block returns, else is not necessary
Same, why not just connect()?
Let's avoid the verb execute. It doesn't pass PoliCheck.
I don't think we can avoid it, it's in our SDK interface and we have to implement it :(
Which SDK? The legacy DeviceClient or the new MultiplexingClient?

For readability, consider putting each condition on a newline:
return status == DISCONNECTED
    && statusChangeReason == RETRY_EXPIRED
    && throwable instanceof DeviceOperationTimeoutException;
Same idea as above, splitting conditions on multiple lines; it will also reduce line length here which is getting a bit long
